Problem:
Consider a function \( z(t) = e^{At}x \) where \( A \) is a constant matrix and \( x \) a constant vector in complex space. The function transforms \( z(t) \) using an operator \( T \) defined as \( Tz = \int_0^T e^{Bt}z(t) \, dt \), where \( B \) is another constant matrix and \( T \) is a fixed terminal time.

If the function \( z(t) \) operates on the vector \( x \) at \( t = 0 \) and evolves according to the transformation \( T \) until \( t = T \) without further intervention, will the resultant \( Tz \) be equivalent to directly applying \( \int_0^T e^{(A+B)t}x \, dt \) on \( x \)?
Explanation: Given the linearity of the integral and exponential functions, \( Tz \) computed as \( \int_0^T e^{Bt}e^{At}x \, dt \) simplifies to \( \int_0^T e^{(A+B)t}x \, dt \). Thus, the direct application of this combined exponential to \( x \) yields the equivalent result.
